Vagner Oliveira Carvalho Rigaud

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/7775544686800920
  • Última atualização do currículo em 12/03/2019

Bacharel em Ciências Biológicas (Genética; 2007), Mestre (2011) e Doutor (2016) em Cardiologia pela Faculdade de Medicina da Universidade de São Paulo (FM-USP). Realizou Pós-doutorado na FM-USP (2017) e na Universidade de Coimbra (2018), Portugal, e atualmente é Pós-doutorando junto ao Laboratory of Stem Cell Biology and Cardiac Regeneration na Temple University, EUA. Possui especial interesse no envolvimento dos microRNAs na progressão de doenças cardiovasculares, bem como no desenvolvimento de inovadoras estratégias terapêuticas e diagnósticas baseadas em RNAs. Possui 23 artigos científicos publicados (índice h= 11); atua como Revisor científico em 22 revistas especializadas; e como Membro de Corpo Editorial em outras 2. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2017 - Atual
Deciphering molecular determinants of human cardiac myofibroblast differentiation using high-content RNAi screening
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Vagner Oliveira Carvalho Rigaud - Coordenador / Miguel Mano - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Fundação para a Ciência e a Tecnologia - Auxílio financeiro.
2016 - Atual
Identification of a predictive/prognostic genetic signature in Chagas Cardiomyopathy: a systems biology approach (Convênio/Acordo de Cooperação Internacional FAPESP/ANR-BLANC-BR-FR-CHAGAS)
Descrição: The main aim of this study is to better understand the mechanisms and genetics of Chagas disease cardiomyopathy using ?omics? approaches. Our main hypothesis is that genetic and epigenetic factors control Chronic Chagas Cardiomyopathy (CCC) progression by way of regulating gene/protein expression profiles and specific disease pathways in affected myocardial tissue. In the previous reports, we have performed a global analysis of the proteome, transcriptome, methylome and MIRNome in heart tissue samples of severe CCC patients. In the present report, we have performed a functional analysis of promoter methylation on expression of 11 genes found to be differentially methylated and expressed in CCC myocardium. We have also performed an integrated analysis of miRNA-gene expression networks in myocardial samples from CCC patients. Regarding the case-control genetic association study of common genetic variants, we have acquired an additional 305 indeterminate form/asymptomatic (ASY) and 197 CCC DNA samples in this period, totaling 502 new samples. The total number of DNA samples in our Chagas disease patient cohort is now 2,066, from which 1285 are CCC 616 are asymptomatic, and 165 cases are still pending the clinical phenotype (external clinical sites will deliver data soon). We will submit these DNA samples to high-throughput global SNP analysis of approximately 700,000 SNPs with the Illumina Infinium SNP microarray Global Screening Assay (GSA). A pilot run of 94 DNA samples from Chagas disease patients showed this tool is highly informative to characterize our main case cohort. For whole exome sequencing (WES) analysis for the detection of rarer susceptibility variants, we have performed a pilot WES of one multicase family, identifying variants on 6 potentially relevant genes that include a mitochondrial gene and ion channels. We have also assembled a group of 22 families with multiple cases of Chagas disease from an endemic area, including 107 subjects, from which we have obtained DNA and serum samples, as well as clinical/epidemiological history, serology, ECG and echocardiogram data. The report is divided in several sections. Each section of the report presents its own independent set of tables and figures (starting in Figure/Table 1 in each section). This report is presented in English because it was presented at the French agency ANR in the same language. In the next steps we will complete the WES analysis of Chagas families and perform the final genotyping step of the 2,000+ Chagas disease samples for the case/control study. Overall, the present report draws light on 11 differentially expressed microRNAs and 56 genes potentially influenced by DNA methylation, microRNAs or coding region mutations. These molecules/regulatory networks deserve further investigation. Taking into account manuscripts that were directly or indirectly related to this project on Chagas disease, we have published 6 papers in 2016.
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Vagner Oliveira Carvalho Rigaud - Integrante / Edécio Cunha Neto - Coordenador / Ludmila Rodrigues Pinto Ferreira - Integrante / Frederico Moraes Ferreira - Integrante / Christophe Chevillard - Integrante.
2016 - Atual
São Paulo-Minas Gerais Neglected Tropical Disease Research Center for Biomarker (SaMi-Trop)
Descrição: Our long term goal is to establish SaMi-Trop as a Center of Excellence for Neglected Infectious Disease Research in Brazil. The Specific Aims of the current application are to begin that process by focusing on T. cruzi infection with the goal of finding an array of biomarkers that correlate with parasite persistence and Chagas cardiac disease that can be used to infer risk of disease progression and death as well used as surrogate markers of cure or efficacy of novel drugs. We will develop two interrelated studies: Project 1 (Principal Investigator Edecio Cunha-Neto) will focus on applying gene expression tools to existing whole blood RNA samples from the NHLBI REDS-II cohort to discover and validate new biomarkers of active infection and disease progression, these will be combined with parasite specific (PCR load and antibody profiling and titers) and plasma proteomic biomarkers (chemokines, cytokines, and inflamatory, coagulation and cardiac parameters) that are being generated through already funded collaborations, to generate composite biomarker profiles and scores that coorelate with pre-defined disease stages.. In Project 2 (Principal Investigator Antonio Ribeiro) we plan to take advantage of the Public Health System in the State of Minas by enrolling and collecting blood samples from 2000 Chagas disease patients. These patients will be followed for two years for the endpoints of death or admission to a hospital for cardiac disease. The main goal is to obtain a simple risk score based on biomarker levels and ECG fndings that could identify high risk patients in order to guide therapeutic approaches and serve as a foundation for future clinical trials.We will also use these samples to validate the utility of biomarkers and composite biomarker profiles found in project 1 for assessment of therapeutic responses including clearance or suppression of parasitemia or normalization of immune perturbations and markers of cardiac damage. Two cores will be established: the Administrative Core and Database and Epidemiology Core that will support activities of the 2 projects, as well as create and sustain research training capacity for young Brazilian scientists.
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Vagner Oliveira Carvalho Rigaud - Integrante / Edécio Cunha Neto - Integrante / Ludmila Rodrigues Pinto Ferreira - Integrante / Ester Cerdeira Sabino - Coordenador.
